div1.opener:

FOR WOMEN
114TH, ST., BET. 7TH AND 8TH AVES.
LILIAN M. ELLIOT, PRINCIPAL
NEW YORK,.....April 11, 1927
A HERO
div1.p:
Did it ever enter your mind to take a small word and analyze
it! If it has, you will find that one little word will afford much
discussion in determining the real meaning. Each one considering the
word will regard it in a different light. So it is with the word “Hero”.
It is indeed a little word but it has a very broad meaning. The Diction-
ary gives the definition of a hero as “A man distinguished for valor,
fortitude or bold enterprises”. How very narrow is this definition
when one considers the word quite fully. We have new heroes every day,
in every part of the world and yet, often, no one knows about them. They
are not advertised for their valor. They are not continually heroes.
One man may give his life for another - he is a hero but he was not
famed for his bold enterprises. And if he does become known for his act,
how long will the fame last? Perhaps he was never even given a thought
by his neighbors until he saved his fellowman. Probably the people who
knew him, thought him an unusual character who had better be left alone
and so he dragged listlessly through life. Yet he had this hidden
attribute - the power to be a hero. His chance came, he saved a man -
gave up his own life for the other and now he is a “hero”.

The meaning of the word lies in the individual conception of it
and one would be surprised to hear all the different versions of a given
number of people. The little girl of seven does not regard a hero in the
same light as her sister of sixteen and her mother has another picture.
Why! Because the viewpoint is decidedly different. Besides this, there are

degrees of heroism. These depend upon the person performing the deed
and his abilities combined with the situation coped with. If a man expects
to perform a heroic act he does not attain the height that another would
who suddenly performs a great deed. A person acting on duty who performs
a great deed is not a hero, because he was put at his post with the idea
that he would perform just such an act, if necessity arose. On the other
hand, if another person comes along who is totally unaware of what is
confronting him, and who, out of love for his fellowman performs the same
deed - he too is a hero. The first man was in duty bound to do the deed
of valor, the other did it spontaneously, with the thought only to prevent
disaster and so he gains the title of “hero”.

If there are so many degrees of heroism what then are the qualities
of a hero? That he must perform a great deed is what most people seem to
think. I disagree because the deed may not be great in the eyes of the
world but when the situation is considered in all its phases, it may be a
deed of great importance. Another quality of a hero is his perseverance in
the face of adversity. We are acquainted with the lines “The man worth
while is the man with a smile when everything goes dead wrong.”
